Little Witch in the Woods ‚Äî Review with 100 hours of pure enchantment
     When I started Little Witch in the Woods, I confess I wasn't expecting so much. I thought it would just be another cute game, maybe quick, a light pastime among other titles. But... what a sweet mistake. With 100 hours of gameplay (and still without getting the platinum trophy, since I do ALL the side quests), today I can say with certainty: this game captivated me a lot.
     The story is divided into chapters, and this structure works wonderfully: each chapter brings new objectives, new areas, and constant evolution not only as a little witch, but as part of the universe. The city that you rebuild together with the residents is a true beating heart: each NPC has a routine, strong personalities, complex and surprising stories that go far beyond what is expected in a "cute little game".
     And if you think that's enough to grab your attention... then the map comes in. Just when you think you've explored everything, unlocked every nook and cranny and mysteries... an even BIGGER area appears, and that makes the game absolutely incredible! There wasn't a single moment I was bored; there's potion crafting, item collection, animals to discover, relationships to build, mysteries, deliveries, puzzles, fishing, and even kittens to adopt! I wish this game was more recognized; it deserves all the love and support... if you're a fan of cozy games, cute things, magic, and witches, I HIGHLY recommend it ‚ô•

My rating: 9.9/10‚≠ê(Request from a fan: The only point I would like you to add is romantic relationships.)

This game take a while for me to get into it and even now (roughly 30 hour for this review) I still have mixed feeling about the game and I just cant quite explain why. Maybe because it not a very active kind of game, there aren't much in term of planing and figuring thing out like similiar game to this that i have played ( Stardew valley, Sun haven, Rune factory).

The gameplay loop of this game is very fitting of Ellie as a character, because she still an apprentice witch so most of the game is about her researching local wild life and making potion. Which is good, I like it when game make sense. But that also where i have problem with the game, the researching part feel like just a list to fill out without any incentive or reason why to do so. The game have some neat idea like if you use correct potion on this dog you can get more material out of it, but then you still have do it the wrong way just because the research tell you to for example. And it doesn't help that some research is completely RNG based and there a fixed amount of wildlife spawning each day, which can very frustrating when you want to get something done. Thankfully you don't really have to do any of it even though a lot of progression is tied to your research level.

Other than that the game is very chill and adorable, and the price is worth it for this game. I can see other people enjoying this game more than myself so if you into cozy game then this is a good one to try out.

Some side note : Just don't try to 100% encyclopedia early on, save it for end game when you have better tool to speed it up. I tried 100% the first area of the game before moving on and it was really boring and tedious process.

I really wish I could give this game a mixed review. This is not exactly a "Stardew Valley-like". There's no farming, but there's ingredient gathering. It does however have the same character interaction system. I did enjoy this game quite a bit, and you might too, but I'm just gonna note down the negatives of the game so that you know what you'll be getting yourself into:
1. There is a SEVERE lack of polish. The loading times (from starting the game to going between areas) are REALLY bad, and it gets worse as you play through the game. There are CONSTANT frame drops. And there's also still a lot of bugs, despite all the patches released.
2. As of writing this, there's still [i]unfinished[/i] content in the game. I'm talking about the characters with incomplete story questlines. You can't have leftover unfinished content in the game in a full release.
3. The story is really nice, but it's also really [i]wordy[/i]. Hours could be dropped from the story if there wasn't as much meaningless yapping.
4. Again, as of writing this, there is no way to rebind controls if you're playing on the controller. The latest patch swapped the keys for "Sort inventory" and "Switch between inventories" in the menu where you interact with a chest, and that left me having to undo 30 hours of built-up muscle memory.

But yeah, apart from that, there's a pretty good game here. Just don't expect the quality of Stardew Valley or similar titles from this game.

Controller controls are easy to use and functions are user-friendly . Overall a really, really great casual game.

CONS - So. much. dialogue. And really - it's not so much the *amount* of dialogue ( though most reviews would argue otherwise ) it's the fact that the translation is..,.rough, to say the very least.  ( and I get it , smaller studio = smaller budget = not a perfect translation ) Honestly I'm just happy the translation is decent enough it can be *mostly* understood, but some things are confusing or not translated well *at all* and some players may find the need to just Google the solution to the quest they are trying to complete.

The latest update added craft from storage and it's amazing. Cute cozy game about making friends and collecting items. Very chill and easy to pick up. 

There isn't a lot of hand-holding and it's sometimes easy to forget what you were working on even though some quests are tracked automatically. 

Pros:
-Craft from storage!
-Easy to learn
-Chill, cozy, nice music (though the town music is a little repetitive after a while)
-Cute characters you build friendships with and learn their backstories. (friendship only, no romancing)
-No combat, just harassing some creatures for their fur
-Collection completion = cute decoration rewards
-Cats you can befriend

Cons:
-I don't like how fast the days go by. It wasn't so bad with only one zone to explore but after you start to open up the town and the other two zones, you really need to pick one task/zone to work on during the day; there's not really enough time to more than one area. There doesn't seem to be any penalty if you do take several days to complete anything so it doesn't really matter, but it's a little frustrating. Especially when the night cycle is a fraction of the day cycle and you have less time for nighttime creatures and plants.
-you can't save right away. there are several (and I mean [i]several[/i]) steps you need to complete before you get the desk in the house to save from unlocked, takes about 30 minutes.
-gameplay gets a little laggy/jittery after awhile, especially when you're running around
-activities don't seem balanced for the amount of energy they use: why does plucking a flower taking 20 energy but fishing only takes 5? I think it takes more effort to haul in a fish than it does to pluck a flower.
-collection requirements don't seem balanced; some are really easy to complete, others are challenging.

Overall, I have really enjoyed this game. I've mostly played while recovering from a shoulder injury so I'm glad it's easy to play on a controller.

I really like this game. It might be the only game of this "type" where I don't feel like I am pressured for time and always have to min/max what I do in a day. It took me a while to even realize that time wasn't paused while in my inventory, and it didn't even matter. I was happy to explore and draw things at my leisure. I love the art and the colors. There's even more dialogue than I had expected, which I'm fine with but I can see why it's a deterrent to others. I like the main character's attitude, and continue to be introduced to new cute things that I didn't know about beforehand.

After 20 hours, there was something unexpected though. I had to upgrade my house to continue the story, and when I came home, the cute house I'd spent all my time in before was gone, replaced with an ugly, massive empty room. This actually made me feel heartbroken. I DO like decorating, but I didn't expect to lose this cozy space that I was so accustomed to. Sure I sometimes clicked on the wrong thing because it was so small, but so what? Now the room is a plain square and I don't think all the furniture in the world is going to make me feel happy about the new space. Plus, I'd been wasting my money beforehand since there was nothing new to buy for a while. Plus, I had to dump my stuff on the floor since chests wouldn't be sold until the next day and I didn't want to leave my junk in the mail. How strange to lose storage space on an upgrade, and what exactly did Kyla do with all the adorable knick-knacks that were present before? ... I had to mention this because it really did change how I felt in the game.

Suddenly I was coming home too late every day, stressing to make money so I wouldn't again miss a shop stocking decorative stuff that I wanted really badly. I had to stop playing for a moment and reframe my mind so that I could enjoy what I was doing again. It reminds me of another game released this year where it took so long to unlock the decorative things I wanted, that I had to spend all my time playing in an ugly space that I didn't like. Coming home to the cozy house at the beginning of Little Witch in the Woods was enjoyable to me. The "upgrade" was a real loss for me.

There are also some unique quirks, I once hadn't used a potion in so long that I turned back from a quest that I could have completed because I had completely forgotten how to do it. I was trying to drink it from my inventory, which you can't do. Then once I remembered, I wasted the potion, because I'd tried standing in the correct position before and couldn't get there, so I didn't try again (I guess it had become stand-able later, or I'd just messed up?).

Anyway, I continue to like everything else new in the game, and I know there's still more to see. I half expected the next "area" I unlocked to feel less content-filled, but it hasn't been. So I still feel like there's more to look forward to and I will continue enjoying the game. 
(just give me back my cozy house? can I trade it in for a smaller square at least? repeated same-style furniture items can't fill this big area without feeling off... I wonder if it can be modded)

Little Witch in the Woods is one I would give a mixed review on if I could like many others. It's got a beautiful pixel art style, charming music and characters, it's cosy but it's hard to praise the gameplay. 

(bonus note; I started playing this game back while it was still being worked on in early access, I'm glad to see it finally got released even if its got it's kinks to work out I wish the team well.)

tl/dr: it's a cute game that needs lot of patience, if you plan on playing it in small bursts to match the slow pace of the game you'll probably like this one and should give it a go. If you don't have a lot of patience and tend to play games for long stretches of time, the bountiful dialogue and a slow pace that can lack on the reward front probably wont be up to your taste.

The pros:

I'm lumping this into one cause it's not a lot sadly. The art style is really simple but cute, sprites have a lot of love put into them and it makes the game feel really lively and fun. I particularly love the portraits of characters, their super well done in both style and expressions. Music is really good. It's fun, whimsical, and also quite relaxing. I'd definitely put it on in the background from time to time for some comfy vibes. (I did have one account where the music got really loud during a cutscene and stayed loud until it finished it's run). Characters are neat, their expressive and really distinct from one another and gave me a good chuckle here and there but some people have noted there's missing dialogue and names later on so bear that in mind...

The Notable Cons:

-Grammar. It's a translated game so hiccups in text are going to pop up, it's a small studio so I can't fault them but it can cause issues for understanding what to do at points. I just find it a shame to see some I saw in the early build are still present in the full release version.

-So much text, and not all in the right place. There's a LOT Of dialogue in the game, this is fun for the story I don't mind if it's there to add to the world, but it really gets in the way when your trying to get something done or when dialogue is repetitive like 'hey you need to know I can also accept candies made despite the prior vendor already telling you that'. Also when I say 'not all in the right place' I mean some places NEEDED more text particularly for tutorials like using the cauldron or notes of 'oh I can't make this thing until I get x' just to nudge the player along sometimes.

-Gameplay is a bit of a repetitive loop with not really anything to break it up. Collect things for potions/candies, fill out book by doing so, make what need in the cauldron, use candies/potions on quests or to progress story, rinse and repeat. Ellie being an apprentice makes sense why it needs to be simple, but I found myself aching for more of a reward or just something else to do especially with the research since it really just unlocks some notes and better drops for the creatures or automations for the potions...

Smaller, quality of life notes;

-I'd rather have purchased recipe's go straight to the book rather than the inventory, I kept forgetting this part because a lot of other games just put a mark on the log/book to say you got it, so I'd go around and do other stuff completely forgetting I never learned the recipe until I need it/inventory full.

-The map is kind of annoying at it's current state. It doesn't tell you what route (marked by a door) leads where, and only shows the area your in rather than offering the entire map. I would love to see the names of areas added to their entrances at the minimum because I kept going the wrong way especially when I wasn't visiting an area frequently.

-The stamina bar needs to be able to get bigger or things need to take less out of it, 300 goes down RAPIDLY when a lot of items need 20 and it doesn't seem like there's any upgraded for it but I am not that deep into the game.

-There are books you can buy but they don't seem to do anything other than just...add more text of a story summary. I had hoped these may have been something to actually read even if short just to pass the time or give a small buff to Ellie even if temporary but they don't. It made wish there was more things to do outside of the crafting of potions/candies and decorating the house (which you don't get for quite awhile!), maybe some minigames like making tea or events with characters, ya know?

[h2]Player-unfriendly in a way that reminds me of a mobile game[/h2] 
I can't recommend LWITW in its current state and I won't be playing the game until at least the localization is improved. I kept pushing through, hoping it would improve, but all I found was more grind, tedium and dialogue that became increasingly frustrating to read due to its frequency and poor English localization. 

Firstly, the controls are clunky and unintuitive. There are too many button presses for everything. If you use a controller, there's no single button mapped for something as essential as opening the map. I eventually found a workaround by: using a controller and remapping the keys for the map, journal, and encyclopedia to my keyboard. I'd use the controller to control Ellie, and I'd use the keyboard for my mapped shortcuts. Without that, I'd first have to press a button to open a ring menu, and then select the map, journal, etc. Even then, both the map and potion encyclopedia required an extra button press to display a more useful view. 

What will really turn people off of the game is the pacing. Everything is slow or has some sort of friction attached to it. Movement is slow because Ellie moves slowly. You have to frequently shuffle between different collection tools with the clunky controls. Nearly every action requires you to press and hold A. With some materials, you have to press A to pick each off of the ground and this is accompanied by an animation. This all starts to add up. 

Early on, your workshop tools are a chore to use. Every item must be processed one at a time. The Extractor is the most painful, with its animations quickly becoming annoying. Later tools like the Mixer and Roaster are slightly better in that they're passive so you can leave them running, but they take upwards of 30 seconds to process an item. You eventually gain access to an Incubator that partially supplants the Extractor, Mixer and Roaster. The Incubator works passively, *and* you can actually purchase multiple, unlike the other tools. The Incubator takes hours to work though, and being able to use it with a specific material is something you have to unlock, with its usage being gated behind collecting that specific material repeatedly in a specific way to fill your encyclopedia. Your Cauldron also eventually lets you brew multiple potions at once, though doing that stands at odds with some of the encyclopedia requirements.

If you're like me, and most of your enjoyment from these types of games comes from obsessively minmaxing and *then* focusing on the rest of the game: you won't be able to do that here. Your progression is gated by the main story. The game may appear to open up after a while, but the bulk of the game is locked behind story progression. New villagers, expanding shop stock, increasing stamina, and accessing upgrades all require sitting through the game's excessive dialogue and fetch quests. I recommend making a beeline for the main story up until you unlock furniture. As for the dialogue, coming from a game like Persona, imagine if regular NPC interactions could be as long as a social link rank up event for no reason. Nearly every small observation made by Ellie, or conversation with a villager feels like it drags on for upwards of 10 extra dialogue windows. There's often some combination of a text overflow issue, missing punctuation, typos and poor English more times than they are not. Any personality or charm the writing may have is killed by the bad English.

Something I really enjoyed at first was the foraging and filling up of the encyclopedia. You catalog items and detail ways to collect them. Every item offers bonuses for gathering it in specific ways or for finding rare variants. Like collect a Bush Bug within 1 second after you shake its bush 10 times. Collect 2 Maple Herb within 10 seconds 10 times, etc. Do that and you hit Rank A. Do those same conditions again 10 times and you hit Rank S, etc. Finished products also have unlockables tied to how many times you create/deliver/use them, but they're not as engaging as the ones for raw materials. Unfortunately, filling the encyclopedia eventually becomes tedious. I made it to the second area which visually looks great, but it also meant new materials to collect and potions to brew. Some of the new materials had collection requirements that were quite tedious compared to the first area. You'll have to collect these new materials over and over again. Collect Item A in X way 10 times, and then 20 times, and then 30 times multiplied by however many new items. So the encyclopedia basically devolved into a grind. 

So overall: your progress will virtually be reset in every new area, there's an inability to reliably earn money outside of your weekly deliveries (and the amount of weekly deliveries available is gated behind grinding), and there are stamina and gold sinks tied to the durability of your cauldron, broom, and the already one-way quick travel gates *and* you have to sometimes choose between efficiency and completing your encyclopedia entries. The stamina system itself is also particularly annoying. Every action actually drains something like -20 Stamina + -10% Max Stamina. So if you gather a few items with 300/300 Stamina, you'll go down to something like 200/250. You can recover your max Stamina, but it requires buying a different type of food, meaning you now need two separate items which means more gold and another item slot just to fully restore yourself. You can forage for free and recover some Stamina, but the foraged berries and fruits restore very little. You can also choose to nap to pass time and recover a little Stamina. Also, good luck if you want to gather at night and accidentally napped for just one hour instead of the maximum of four, because then Ellie will say that she's not tired and you'll have to wait 3 in-game hours. The game also blocks you from napping before 8PM, presumably so you can't just sleep through to your weekly deliveries. All of this combined makes the game player-unfriendly in a way that reminds me of a mobile game. 

Aside from foraging, potion making is the other major thing you'll be doing. Unfortunately, potion making is quite simple and nearly every mechanic present just feels like a gimmick throw in to slow you down after you spent so much time refining your raw materials. Making a couple of potions in a row for your weekly deliveries is tedium.

When you're not upgrading your workshop through Luna Coins (that are earned separately from Gold Coins and used for specific things) or befriending villagers, you can use your Gold Coins (that is earned separately from Luna Coins and used for specific things) to purchase furniture. There's a surprising amount of furniture (and they're cute!) to unlock, but decoration is really just that. Furniture has no impact (not a problem for me personally) other than making your house and workshop look cute. The shop system could use some QoL additions here, since it doesn't tell you what items or furniture you already own, so unless you keep track of that yourself then you'll be wasting gold. 

Visually, the game is really cute. I love the pixel art, and especially the second major area. However, the music is often too tranquil to the point of being barely present. I also found the workshop having no music being a little jarring. On the technical side, I experienced no crashes, though loading screens could be a little long and sometimes freeze slightly. The only issue I had was my house suddenly having black wallpaper and tiles until I reapplied my custom wallpaper and tiles to fix it.

TL;DR: this is a slow-paced, dialogue-heavy, whimsical slice-of-life RPG with collectathon and crafting elements, but it suffers from an overly verbose and badly translated script and does nearly everything it can to make you more and more frustrated. There's an enjoyable core here for sure, but the devs need to add a lot more polish.

I've played the game for a considerable amount of time, and while I find the main game play to be fun, the translated dialog and visuals tend to be a bit lazy. My largest gripe tends to be with the dialog being repetitive and just awkward to read through. While I can typically ignore the usual grammatical error from a company who's main language is not English, it's hard to ignore when the game is heavily text based and revolves around relationships and community. It is hard to feel connected to any of the characters because they are just frustrating to read with this translation. I would much rather just get the quests over and done with then really take the time to get to understand their individual personalities. While I cannot for sure know if this tidbit is true or not, I have heard that this game is *only* machine translated, which would make sense since the awkwardness of the text could be because it is a literal translation without the context of how those sentences would work in the English sentence structure.

My issues with the visuals tend to boil down to there being little to no clean up work. The sprites and animations are fun and lovely, however, there are some areas where corners were cut, especially in the localization. Sometimes, translated text will *overflow* the box, making it so there is text bleed above and below where it should be. This of course is very visually distracting and a tad hard to read through. Virgil's text can also do something similar where the font is squashed and squished to fit his text box. While the idea of him having his own box is neat and makes sense so he doesn't take up the main box as he tends to typically only have witty remarks, it is really distracting to see the kerning of the font get changed so often depending on how much he is saying. While I will agree this last part is a bit picky on my end, sometimes the animations are strange in the game, especially when things are moving to different levels of elevation. While we may have a map with visible elevation, such as a hill or slope.  the animations treat it as if it's a flat surface for anything interacting with it. This gives the impression that the character isn't changing elevations but is just in a static area. Sometimes, I've had issues with catching bush bugs because of this elevation trickery as well, but by far, it's not the worst contender in this review, but it's still distracting. 

I really want to be able to recommend this game as I think it's really fun and I like cozy games like this, there are too many issues post launch for me to feel comfortable to praise it. Who knows, maybe these issues will be fixed and I will be able to recommend it in good faith later. I'll be keeping a keen eye on this project until then.

[h2]Player-unfriendly in a way that reminds me of a mobile game[/h2] 
I can't recommend LWITW in its current state and I won't be playing the game until at least the localization is improved. I kept pushing through, hoping it would improve, but all I found was more grind, tedium and dialogue that became increasingly frustrating to read due to its frequency and poor English localization. 

Firstly, the controls are clunky and unintuitive. There are too many button presses for everything. If you use a controller, there's no single button mapped for something as essential as opening the map. I eventually found a workaround by: using a controller and remapping the keys for the map, journal, and encyclopedia to my keyboard. I'd use the controller to control Ellie, and I'd use the keyboard for my mapped shortcuts. Without that, I'd first have to press a button to open a ring menu, and then select the map, journal, etc. Even then, both the map and potion encyclopedia required an extra button press to display a more useful view. 

What will really turn people off of the game is the pacing. Everything is slow or has some sort of friction attached to it. Movement is slow because Ellie moves slowly. You have to frequently shuffle between different collection tools with the clunky controls. Nearly every action requires you to press and hold A. With some materials, you have to press A to pick each off of the ground and this is accompanied by an animation. This all starts to add up. 

Early on, your workshop tools are a chore to use. Every item must be processed one at a time. The Extractor is the most painful, with its animations quickly becoming annoying. Later tools like the Mixer and Roaster are slightly better in that they're passive so you can leave them running, but they take upwards of 30 seconds to process an item. You eventually gain access to an Incubator that partially supplants the Extractor, Mixer and Roaster. The Incubator works passively, *and* you can actually purchase multiple, unlike the other tools. The Incubator takes hours to work though, and being able to use it with a specific material is something you have to unlock, with its usage being gated behind collecting that specific material repeatedly in a specific way to fill your encyclopedia. Your Cauldron also eventually lets you brew multiple potions at once, though doing that stands at odds with some of the encyclopedia requirements.

If you're like me, and most of your enjoyment from these types of games comes from obsessively minmaxing and *then* focusing on the rest of the game: you won't be able to do that here. Your progression is gated by the main story. The game may appear to open up after a while, but the bulk of the game is locked behind story progression. New villagers, expanding shop stock, increasing stamina, and accessing upgrades all require sitting through the game's excessive dialogue and fetch quests. I recommend making a beeline for the main story up until you unlock furniture. As for the dialogue, coming from a game like Persona, imagine if regular NPC interactions could be as long as a social link rank up event for no reason. Nearly every small observation made by Ellie, or conversation with a villager feels like it drags on for upwards of 10 extra dialogue windows. There's often some combination of a text overflow issue, missing punctuation, typos and poor English more times than they are not. Any personality or charm the writing may have is killed by the bad English.

Something I really enjoyed at first was the foraging and filling up of the encyclopedia. You catalog items and detail ways to collect them. Every item offers bonuses for gathering it in specific ways or for finding rare variants. Like collect a Bush Bug within 1 second after you shake its bush 10 times. Collect 2 Maple Herb within 10 seconds 10 times, etc. Do that and you hit Rank A. Do those same conditions again 10 times and you hit Rank S, etc. Finished products also have unlockables tied to how many times you create/deliver/use them, but they're not as engaging as the ones for raw materials. Unfortunately, filling the encyclopedia eventually becomes tedious. I made it to the second area which visually looks great, but it also meant new materials to collect and potions to brew. Some of the new materials had collection requirements that were quite tedious compared to the first area. You'll have to collect these new materials over and over again. Collect Item A in X way 10 times, and then 20 times, and then 30 times multiplied by however many new items. So the encyclopedia basically devolved into a grind. 

So overall: your progress will virtually be reset in every new area, there's an inability to reliably earn money outside of your weekly deliveries (and the amount of weekly deliveries available is gated behind grinding), and there are stamina and gold sinks tied to the durability of your cauldron, broom, and the already one-way quick travel gates *and* you have to sometimes choose between efficiency and completing your encyclopedia entries. The stamina system itself is also particularly annoying. Every action actually drains something like -20 Stamina + -10% Max Stamina. So if you gather a few items with 300/300 Stamina, you'll go down to something like 200/250. You can recover your max Stamina, but it requires buying a different type of food, meaning you now need two separate items which means more gold and another item slot just to fully restore yourself. You can forage for free and recover some Stamina, but the foraged berries and fruits restore very little. You can also choose to nap to pass time and recover a little Stamina. Also, good luck if you want to gather at night and accidentally napped for just one hour instead of the maximum of four, because then Ellie will say that she's not tired and you'll have to wait 3 in-game hours. The game also blocks you from napping before 8PM, presumably so you can't just sleep through to your weekly deliveries. All of this combined makes the game player-unfriendly in a way that reminds me of a mobile game. 

Aside from foraging, potion making is the other major thing you'll be doing. Unfortunately, potion making is quite simple and nearly every mechanic present just feels like a gimmick throw in to slow you down after you spent so much time refining your raw materials. Making a couple of potions in a row for your weekly deliveries is tedium.

When you're not upgrading your workshop through Luna Coins (that are earned separately from Gold Coins and used for specific things) or befriending villagers, you can use your Gold Coins (that is earned separately from Luna Coins and used for specific things) to purchase furniture. There's a surprising amount of furniture (and they're cute!) to unlock, but decoration is really just that. Furniture has no impact (not a problem for me personally) other than making your house and workshop look cute. The shop system could use some QoL additions here, since it doesn't tell you what items or furniture you already own, so unless you keep track of that yourself then you'll be wasting gold. 

Visually, the game is really cute. I love the pixel art, and especially the second major area. However, the music is often too tranquil to the point of being barely present. I also found the workshop having no music being a little jarring. On the technical side, I experienced no crashes, though loading screens could be a little long and sometimes freeze slightly. The only issue I had was my house suddenly having black wallpaper and tiles until I reapplied my custom wallpaper and tiles to fix it.

TL;DR: this is a slow-paced, dialogue-heavy, whimsical slice-of-life RPG with collectathon and crafting elements, but it suffers from an overly verbose and badly translated script and does nearly everything it can to make you more and more frustrated. There's an enjoyable core here for sure, but the devs need to add a lot more polish.

I've played the game for a considerable amount of time, and while I find the main game play to be fun, the translated dialog and visuals tend to be a bit lazy. My largest gripe tends to be with the dialog being repetitive and just awkward to read through. While I can typically ignore the usual grammatical error from a company who's main language is not English, it's hard to ignore when the game is heavily text based and revolves around relationships and community. It is hard to feel connected to any of the characters because they are just frustrating to read with this translation. I would much rather just get the quests over and done with then really take the time to get to understand their individual personalities. While I cannot for sure know if this tidbit is true or not, I have heard that this game is *only* machine translated, which would make sense since the awkwardness of the text could be because it is a literal translation without the context of how those sentences would work in the English sentence structure.

My issues with the visuals tend to boil down to there being little to no clean up work. The sprites and animations are fun and lovely, however, there are some areas where corners were cut, especially in the localization. Sometimes, translated text will *overflow* the box, making it so there is text bleed above and below where it should be. This of course is very visually distracting and a tad hard to read through. Virgil's text can also do something similar where the font is squashed and squished to fit his text box. While the idea of him having his own box is neat and makes sense so he doesn't take up the main box as he tends to typically only have witty remarks, it is really distracting to see the kerning of the font get changed so often depending on how much he is saying. While I will agree this last part is a bit picky on my end, sometimes the animations are strange in the game, especially when things are moving to different levels of elevation. While we may have a map with visible elevation, such as a hill or slope.  the animations treat it as if it's a flat surface for anything interacting with it. This gives the impression that the character isn't changing elevations but is just in a static area. Sometimes, I've had issues with catching bush bugs because of this elevation trickery as well, but by far, it's not the worst contender in this review, but it's still distracting. 

I really want to be able to recommend this game as I think it's really fun and I like cozy games like this, there are too many issues post launch for me to feel comfortable to praise it. Who knows, maybe these issues will be fixed and I will be able to recommend it in good faith later. I'll be keeping a keen eye on this project until then.

[h2]Player-unfriendly in a way that reminds me of a mobile game[/h2] 
I can't recommend LWITW in its current state and I won't be playing the game until at least the localization is improved. I kept pushing through, hoping it would improve, but all I found was more grind, tedium and dialogue that became increasingly frustrating to read due to its frequency and poor English localization. 

Firstly, the controls are clunky and unintuitive. There are too many button presses for everything. If you use a controller, there's no single button mapped for something as essential as opening the map. I eventually found a workaround by: using a controller and remapping the keys for the map, journal, and encyclopedia to my keyboard. I'd use the controller to control Ellie, and I'd use the keyboard for my mapped shortcuts. Without that, I'd first have to press a button to open a ring menu, and then select the map, journal, etc. Even then, both the map and potion encyclopedia required an extra button press to display a more useful view. 

What will really turn people off of the game is the pacing. Everything is slow or has some sort of friction attached to it. Movement is slow because Ellie moves slowly. You have to frequently shuffle between different collection tools with the clunky controls. Nearly every action requires you to press and hold A. With some materials, you have to press A to pick each off of the ground and this is accompanied by an animation. This all starts to add up. 

Early on, your workshop tools are a chore to use. Every item must be processed one at a time. The Extractor is the most painful, with its animations quickly becoming annoying. Later tools like the Mixer and Roaster are slightly better in that they're passive so you can leave them running, but they take upwards of 30 seconds to process an item. You eventually gain access to an Incubator that partially supplants the Extractor, Mixer and Roaster. The Incubator works passively, *and* you can actually purchase multiple, unlike the other tools. The Incubator takes hours to work though, and being able to use it with a specific material is something you have to unlock, with its usage being gated behind collecting that specific material repeatedly in a specific way to fill your encyclopedia. Your Cauldron also eventually lets you brew multiple potions at once, though doing that stands at odds with some of the encyclopedia requirements.

If you're like me, and most of your enjoyment from these types of games comes from obsessively minmaxing and *then* focusing on the rest of the game: you won't be able to do that here. Your progression is gated by the main story. The game may appear to open up after a while, but the bulk of the game is locked behind story progression. New villagers, expanding shop stock, increasing stamina, and accessing upgrades all require sitting through the game's excessive dialogue and fetch quests. I recommend making a beeline for the main story up until you unlock furniture. As for the dialogue, coming from a game like Persona, imagine if regular NPC interactions could be as long as a social link rank up event for no reason. Nearly every small observation made by Ellie, or conversation with a villager feels like it drags on for upwards of 10 extra dialogue windows. There's often some combination of a text overflow issue, missing punctuation, typos and poor English more times than they are not. Any personality or charm the writing may have is killed by the bad English.

Something I really enjoyed at first was the foraging and filling up of the encyclopedia. You catalog items and detail ways to collect them. Every item offers bonuses for gathering it in specific ways or for finding rare variants. Like collect a Bush Bug within 1 second after you shake its bush 10 times. Collect 2 Maple Herb within 10 seconds 10 times, etc. Do that and you hit Rank A. Do those same conditions again 10 times and you hit Rank S, etc. Finished products also have unlockables tied to how many times you create/deliver/use them, but they're not as engaging as the ones for raw materials. Unfortunately, filling the encyclopedia eventually becomes tedious. I made it to the second area which visually looks great, but it also meant new materials to collect and potions to brew. Some of the new materials had collection requirements that were quite tedious compared to the first area. You'll have to collect these new materials over and over again. Collect Item A in X way 10 times, and then 20 times, and then 30 times multiplied by however many new items. So the encyclopedia basically devolved into a grind. 

So overall: your progress will virtually be reset in every new area, there's an inability to reliably earn money outside of your weekly deliveries (and the amount of weekly deliveries available is gated behind grinding), and there are stamina and gold sinks tied to the durability of your cauldron, broom, and the already one-way quick travel gates *and* you have to sometimes choose between efficiency and completing your encyclopedia entries. The stamina system itself is also particularly annoying. Every action actually drains something like -20 Stamina + -10% Max Stamina. So if you gather a few items with 300/300 Stamina, you'll go down to something like 200/250. You can recover your max Stamina, but it requires buying a different type of food, meaning you now need two separate items which means more gold and another item slot just to fully restore yourself. You can forage for free and recover some Stamina, but the foraged berries and fruits restore very little. You can also choose to nap to pass time and recover a little Stamina. Also, good luck if you want to gather at night and accidentally napped for just one hour instead of the maximum of four, because then Ellie will say that she's not tired and you'll have to wait 3 in-game hours. The game also blocks you from napping before 8PM, presumably so you can't just sleep through to your weekly deliveries. All of this combined makes the game player-unfriendly in a way that reminds me of a mobile game. 

Aside from foraging, potion making is the other major thing you'll be doing. Unfortunately, potion making is quite simple and nearly every mechanic present just feels like a gimmick throw in to slow you down after you spent so much time refining your raw materials. Making a couple of potions in a row for your weekly deliveries is tedium.

When you're not upgrading your workshop through Luna Coins (that are earned separately from Gold Coins and used for specific things) or befriending villagers, you can use your Gold Coins (that is earned separately from Luna Coins and used for specific things) to purchase furniture. There's a surprising amount of furniture (and they're cute!) to unlock, but decoration is really just that. Furniture has no impact (not a problem for me personally) other than making your house and workshop look cute. The shop system could use some QoL additions here, since it doesn't tell you what items or furniture you already own, so unless you keep track of that yourself then you'll be wasting gold. 

Visually, the game is really cute. I love the pixel art, and especially the second major area. However, the music is often too tranquil to the point of being barely present. I also found the workshop having no music being a little jarring. On the technical side, I experienced no crashes, though loading screens could be a little long and sometimes freeze slightly. The only issue I had was my house suddenly having black wallpaper and tiles until I reapplied my custom wallpaper and tiles to fix it.

TL;DR: this is a slow-paced, dialogue-heavy, whimsical slice-of-life RPG with collectathon and crafting elements, but it suffers from an overly verbose and badly translated script and does nearly everything it can to make you more and more frustrated. There's an enjoyable core here for sure, but the devs need to add a lot more polish.

My largest gripe tends to be with the dialog being repetitive and just awkward to read through. While I can typically ignore the usual grammatical error from a company who's main language is not English, it's hard to ignore when the game is heavily text based and revolves around relationships and community. It is hard to feel connected to any of the characters because they are just frustrating to read with this translation. I would much rather just get the quests over and done with then really take the time to get to understand their individual personalities. While I cannot for sure know if this tidbit is true or not, I have heard that this game is *only* machine translated, which would make sense since the awkwardness of the text could be because it is a literal translation without the context of how those sentences would work in the English sentence structure.

My issues with the visuals tend to boil down to there being little to no clean up work. The sprites and animations are fun and lovely, however, there are some areas where corners were cut, especially in the localization. Sometimes, translated text will *overflow* the box, making it so there is text bleed above and below where it should be. This of course is very visually distracting and a tad hard to read through. Virgil's text can also do something similar where the font is squashed and squished to fit his text box. While the idea of him having his own box is neat and makes sense so he doesn't take up the main box as he tends to typically only have witty remarks, it is really distracting to see the kerning of the font get changed so often depending on how much he is saying. While I will agree this last part is a bit picky on my end, sometimes the animations are strange in the game, especially when things are moving to different levels of elevation. While we may have a map with visible elevation, such as a hill or slope.  the animations treat it as if it's a flat surface for anything interacting with it. This gives the impression that the character isn't changing elevations but is just in a static area. Sometimes, I've had issues with catching bush bugs because of this elevation trickery as well, but by far, it's not the worst contender in this review, but it's still distracting. 

I really want to be able to recommend this game as I think it's really fun and I like cozy games like this, there are too many issues post launch for me to feel comfortable to praise it. Who knows, maybe these issues will be fixed and I will be able to recommend it in good faith later. I'll be keeping a keen eye on this project until then.

Very cute, and fun concept, but too many incredibly basic bugs for me to recommend it.

One example; there's a side quest early on to research the Squishychub. But if you've already researched it before getting the quest? You can NEVER complete the quest. It doesn't auto-complete because the task is done it's just a stuck quest that can never be completed. In alpha or even beta this is fair enough, but unacceptable for a game that's considered fully released.

This one is smaller but, stairs that go left/right don't animate like stairs, you just go straight across as if it's flat ground. This doesn't break the game or anything, but even the most amateur of indie games manages to get something so basic correctly, and it is very immersion breaking. Another thing that might be fine for early access but unacceptable for a released game.

I don't doubt if I kept playing I'd find more problems, but being confronted with these issues, especially the quest one which just breaks your ability to complete parts of the game, are enough that I cannot recommend buying this.
